facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1090 of 1967 is an appeal from the judgment and decree dated May 5, 1966 of the Gujarat High Court in S.C.A. No. 877 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1090 of 1967. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated May 5, 1966 of the Gujarat High Court in S.C.A. No. 877 of 1962.

facts.text: The appeal arises out of one of seventy Special Civil applications filed in the Gujarat High Court by rate payers challenging the validity of property tax assessment by the respondent-Corporation under the Bombay Provincial Municipal Corporations Act, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, by certificate, arises out of one of the seventy Special Civil applications filed in the High Court of Gujarat by several- rate payers challenging the Validity of the assessment of property tax made by the respondent-Corporation under the Bombay Provincial Municipal Corporations Act, LIX of 1949  hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: The appellant is the owner of an immovable property situated within the limits of the Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the owner of an immovable property situate within the limits of the Corporation.

facts.text: Until March 31, 1961, two kinds of taxes were levied: general tax by Corporation under the Act, and urban immovable property tax under Bombay Finance Act, 1932 by State Government, collected by Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: Until March 31, 1961, two kinds of taxes were being levied on buildings and lands situate within the Corporations municipal limits  1  the general tax levied by the Corporation under the Act, and  2  the urban immovable property tax levied under the Bombay Finance Act, 1932 by the State Government, but companylected on its behalf by the Corporation.

facts.text: In 1960, at the request of the Corporation, an arrangement was made between Government and Corporation where Government agreed not to levy U.I.P. tax if Corporation increased the property tax rate.

anchor.surface_text: At the request of the Corporation made in 1960, an arrangement was arrived at between the Government and the Corporation where under the Government agreed number to levy the U.I.P. tax provided the Corporation increased the rate at which it was till then levying the property tax.

facts.text: In January 1961, the Corporation passed a resolution increasing the rate of property tax with effect from April 1, 1961 under S. 127 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, in January 1961 the Corporation passed a resolution in,creasing the rate of the property tax with effect from April 1, 1961 under the power reserved to it by S. 127 of the Act.

facts.text: In pursuance of the resolution, the Corporation served bills and demand notices on the appellant and other rate payers for the assessment year 1962-63.

anchor.surface_text: In 94 5 pursuance of the said resolution and in accordance with the raised percentage of the general tax the Corporation served on the appellant, as also on the other rate payers, bills and demand numberices.

facts.text: The appellant challenged the bills and notices in writ petition on grounds including lack of authority to amend rates to include U.I.P. tax, illegal assessment-book not authenticated, and unconstitutionality of sections 99, 123, 129(c).

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, as also certain other rate payers, challenged the said bills and numberices in their said writ petitions mainly on the grounds  1  that the Corporation had numberauthority to amend the rates with the object of including the said U.I.P. tax in the general tax so far levied by the Government under a different statute and given up by it under the said arrangement  2  that the said bills and numberices were illegal as the assessment-book kept by the Cor- poration was number in accordance with the rules made under the Act and was number authenticated by the Commissioner as required thereunder  3  that ss. 99, 123 and 129 c  of the Act were unconstitutional...

facts.text: By judgment dated May 5, 1966, Gujarat High Court disposed of 52 writ petitions rejecting contentions.

anchor.surface_text: By its judgment dated May 5, 1966, the High Court first dis- posed of fifty two out of the said seventy writ petitions rejecting the companytentions raised therein.

facts.text: High Court judgment under review disposed of remaining 18 petitions including appellant's, based on earlier judgment.

anchor.surface_text: There after the judgment under review separately disposed of the remaining 18 petitions, including that of the appellant, as, besides the points raised in the said 52 writ petitions, these 18 writ petitions raised some additional points.

facts.text: High Court held that Corporation need not maintain separate assessment-book for each ward and could maintain one for all wards.

anchor.surface_text: In its judgment, dated the May 5, 1966, the High Court elaborately examined the scheme and the objects, of the Act and the rules and came to the following companyclusions  1  that the Corporation need number maintain separate assessment-book for each of the wards and companyld legally maintain one assessment-book companyering all the wards

facts.text: High Court held authentication under r.19 not mandatory.

anchor.surface_text: 2  that the authentication provided for by r. 19 of the said rules in Ch. VIII to Sch. A of the Act ,as number mandatory

facts.text: High Court held liability to pay tax arises when entry under r.9(e) made in assessment-book.

anchor.surface_text: 3  that the liability to pay the tax arose when entry under r. 9 e  was made in the assessment-book and  4 that s. 129  c  read with ss. 99 and 127 did number suffer from the vice of excessive delegation

facts.text: High Court held ss.99,123,129(c) do not suffer from excessive delegation.

anchor.surface_text: 4 that s. 129  c  read with ss. 99 and 127 did number suffer from the vice of excessive delegation as the legislature had provided in the Act both its policy and principles guiding the Corporation in levying the said tax.

facts.text: Each year the Commissioner prepared or continued the assessment-book under Taxation Rules.

anchor.surface_text: Broadly stated, the facts regarding the assessment-book and its authentication are as follows Each year the Commissioner either prepared or companytinued the assessment- book required to be maintained by him under the Taxation Rules.

facts.text: Each year Commissioner authenticated the assessment-book under r.19.

anchor.surface_text: Each year he went through the procedure for authentication of the assessment-book purporting to do so under r. 19 of the Taxation Rules.

facts.text: After authentication, Commissioner issued certificate that no valid objection received per cl.(e) r.9, then Corporation issued bills and demand notices.

anchor.surface_text: After 9 4 7 the assessment-book was authenticated, as aforesaid, and a certificate was issued by him that numbervalid objection had been received in respect of the rateable values entered in the assessment-book as required by cl.  e  of r. 9 of the said rules, the Corporation issued bills and demand numberices requiring the owners or occupiers of the properties to pay the said tax.

facts.text: Appellant raised three contentions in appeal, later gave up the third regarding circumstances of resolution.

anchor.surface_text: We need number go into all the diverse companytentions raised before the High Court as companynsel for the appellant raised before us the following three questions only ... Later, Mr. lyengar gave up, the third companytention.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal challenges: no ward assessment-books maintained, no authentication per r.19; S.129 excessive delegation.

anchor.surface_text: We are, there fore, left with his companytentions  1  and  2  only for determination. 1 that while making the, assessment the procedure companytemplated by ss. 127, 129 c  of the Act and rr. 9 to 20 of the Taxation Rules was number companynplied with inasmuch as numberward assessment-books were maintained...

facts.text: Gujarat State Legislature amended cl.(c) of S.129 by Act 8 of 1968 inserting maximum rate of 30%.

anchor.surface_text: We may numbere that the Gujarat State Legislature, by Act 8 of 1968, has recently amended cl.  c  by inserting therein the maximum rate of 30, so that the question as to the absence of maximum rate is relevant only for the assessment years prior to the amendment.

holdings.text: Section 129 does not suffer from excessive delegation of legislative power as the Act provides policy, guidelines, and controls over the Corporation's taxing power.

anchor.surface_text: The question thus is whether the Act contains any policy or guidelines or control over the taxing power of the Corporation without which the delegation of power to tax would be excessive, arbitrary and violative of Art. 14. The Act, as its preamble and the long title show, was passed for establishment of municipal companyporations in the city of Ahemedabad and Poona and certain other cities for ensuring better municipal government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act limits taxes to its purposes (s.127), budget controls (ss.82-100), elected councillors, govt sanction on rules (ss.454-457); follows Liberty Cinema, Birla Mills; distinguishes sales tax delegation.

holdings.text: In view of the decisions cited, it is not possible to agree that the Act confers arbitrary and uncontrolled power rendering it excessive delegation.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the decisions cited above it is number possible for us to agree with companynsels companytention that the Act companyfers on the Corporation such arbitrary and uncontrolled power as to ren- der such companyferment an excessive delegation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Elected body delegation, purposes of Act as limit, budget process, judicial review; govt can amend as done in 1968.

holdings.text: Rule 10(1) is permissive; Commissioner has option to maintain one assessment-book or separate ward assessment-books.

anchor.surface_text: On a plain meaning of the language in r. 10 the Commissioner has the option to maintain either one assessment-book or ward assessment-books separately for each ward.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual: 'may, if thinks fit'; deliberate departure from Bombay Act s.157 for varying cities.

holdings.text: Rules 13, 15, and 19 apply to a single assessment-book; expression 'ward assessment-book' retained through inadvertence.

anchor.surface_text: the companyclusion we must reach is that it was through inadvertence that the old language used in ss. 157 to 168 of the Bombay Corporation Act was allowed to be retained without carrying out the change of language necessitated as a result of r. 10 giving discretion to the Commissioner either to maintain one book or several books wardwise.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Avoids anomalies in inspection, complaints, authentication; object is conclusiveness for single or ward books post r.10 change.

holdings.text: Rule 19 authentication applies even where one assessment-book is maintained, making entries conclusive evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 19, therefore, was intended to enable the Corporation to proceed to make demands so soon as entries are made as provided by cl. e of r. 9 and the Commission has given thereafter his authentication that there exists numbervalid objection to the rateable value entered under the said cl. e .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Object: conclusiveness for billing; cannot apply only to ward books given r.10 option; High Court erred on this.

holdings.text: Liability to pay property tax arises under r.9(e) and r.30 upon entry after rates fixed and objections disposed, independent of r.19 authentication.
holdings.reasoning_summary: r.9(e) timing after rates/objections; authentication evidentiary only; agrees with High Court.

holdings.text: The assessment-book is valid; no objection to bills and demand notices sustainable on ground of single book instead of ward books.

anchor.surface_text: The result, therefore, is that the assessment-book in question must be held to be valid and numberobjection as to the validity of the bills and demand numberices can be raised on the ground that only one assessment-book and number wardwise books are kept.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedure under ss.127,129(c), rr.9-20 complied via permissive r.10, inadvertence in rules.

holdings.text: Appellant fails on both contentions; appeal dismissed implicitly.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, thus, does number succeed on either of the two companytentions raised on his behalf.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects both main grounds challenging tax validity.

precedents.citation: Corporation of Calcutta v. Liberty Cinema, 1

anchor.surface_text: the Corporation of Calcutta v. Liberty Cinema, 1 wherein the validity of s. 548 2 of the Calcutta Municipal Act, authorising the Corporation to levy a fee  held by this Court to be a tax  for every licence and permission at such rate as may be fixed from time to time by the Corporation. but which did number lay down the maximum rate, was challenged. The High Court in particular relied on the observations in that decision  1  that fixation of the rate was number an esserxtial legislative function and companyld be delegated, and  2  that the provisions in the Act, which limited the power to levy taxes to the extent of the statutory needs of the Corporation, furnished sufficient companytrol and guidance.

precedents.case_name: Corporation of Calcutta v Liberty Cinema
precedents.cited_proposition: fixation of the rate was not an essential legislative function and could be delegated; provisions limiting levy of taxes to statutory needs of Corporation furnish sufficient control and guidance; absence of maximum rate does not invalidate delegation as maximum is limit not guidance

precedents.citation: Municipal Corporation of the City of Ahmedabad v. Zaveri Keshavtal 1

anchor.surface_text: The High Court distinguished its earlier decision in the Municipal Corporation of the City of Ahmedabad v. Zaveri Keshavtal 1  by pointing out that that decision was under the Bombay  1  6 Guj. L.R.701. Municipal Boroughs Acts, 1925 which had a scheme and pro- visions different from the present Act and the rules thereunder made. That decision had laid down that the liability of the rate payer would arise only after authentication of the assessmentbook.

precedents.case_name: Municipal Corporation of the City of Ahmedabad v Zaveri Keshavtal
precedents.cited_proposition: liability to pay tax arises only after authentication of the assessment book

precedents.citation: The Western India Theatres Ltd. v. Municipal Corporation of the City of Poona 1

anchor.surface_text: In The Western India Theatres Ltd. v. Municipal Corporation of the City of Poona 1  this Court spelt out the policy in the expression for the purposes of this Act, an expression also used in S. 127. In Pandit Banarsi Das Bhanot v. Madhya Pradesh 2 , delegation of power to the executive to determine the details relating to the working of taxation laws, such as the selection of persons on whom the tax is to be levied the rates at which it is to be charged in respect of different classes of goods and the like, was held number to be unconstitutional on the principle that so long as the legislature retains or has the power of withdrawing or altering the power to tax delegated to a subordinate authority such delegation would be held neither an abdication number excessive.

precedents.case_name: Western India Theatres Ltd v Municipal Corporation of the City of Poona
precedents.cited_proposition: policy spelt out in the expression 'for the purposes of this Act'

precedents.citation: Pandit Banarsi Das Bhanot v. Madhya Pradesh 2

anchor.surface_text: In Pandit Banarsi Das Bhanot v. Madhya Pradesh 2 , delegation of power to the executive to determine the details relating to the working of taxation laws, such as the selection of persons on whom the tax is to be levied the rates at which it is to be charged in respect of different classes of goods and the like, was held number to be unconstitutional on the principle that so long as the legislature retains or has the power of withdrawing or altering the power to tax delegated to a subordinate authority such delegation would be held neither an abdication number excessive. In Liberty Cinema case 3  the majority view was that the power to fix the rate of a tax was number of the essence of the legislative power and that such a power companyld be delegated even to a number-legislative body.

precedents.case_name: Pandit Banarsi Das Bhanot v Madhya Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: delegation to executive for details of taxation laws (selection of persons, rates etc.) not unconstitutional if legislature retains power to withdraw or alter

anchor.surface_text: In Liberty Cinema case 3  the majority view was that the power to fix the rate of a tax was number of the essence of the legislative power and that such a power companyld be delegated even to a number-legislative body. But the decision laid down that when such a power is delegated, the legislature must provide guidance for such fixation. The majority held that where rates have number been specified in the statute, the power to fix the rates as might be necessary to meet the needs of the delegate itself affords guidance.  3  19652 S.C.R. 477.

precedents.case_name: Corporation of Calcutta v Liberty Cinema
precedents.cited_proposition: power to fix rate of tax not essence of legislative power and delegable even to non-legislative body if legislature provides guidance; needs of delegate afford guidance

anchor.surface_text: The Liberty Cinema case 3  came for consideration in Devi Das v. Punjab 4  where Subba Rao, C.J., speaking for the Court, said  1 1959 Sup, 2 S.C.R.71.  2  1959 S.C.R.427.  3  19652 S.C.R. 477.  4 1967 3 S.C.R. 557. If this decision Liberty Cinema case 1  is an authority for the position that the Legislature can delegate its power to a statutory authority to levy taxes and fix rates in regard thereto, it is equally an authority for the position that the said statute to be valid must give a guidance to the said authority for fixing the said rates.

precedents.cited_proposition: Liberty Cinema requires guidance for delegation of power to fix tax rates; distinguished sales tax from municipal tax delegation

precedents.citation: Municipal Corporation of Delhi v. Birla MilIS 3

anchor.surface_text: In the Municipal Corporation of Delhi v. Birla MilIS 3 , the question as to the limits of delegation of taxing power once more arose. The Delhi Municipal Corporation Act, 1957, like the present Act, entrusted to the Delhi Corporation two kinds of functions, compulsory and optional. In relation to the former, the Act specified the maximum rate of tax the Corporation companyld raise, but number so in the case of tax relating to or for implementing the optional functions.  3  1968 3  S.C.R.251.

precedents.case_name: Municipal Corporation of Delhi v Birla Mills
precedents.cited_proposition: guidance for municipal tax delegation provided by elected body responsible to people, purposes of Act, budget provisions, judicial review; absence of max rate alone does not invalidate; distinction from sales tax

outcome.relief_summary: Appellant's contentions on excessive delegation and validity of assessment-book rejected; levy of property tax upheld; appeal dismissed
